description: Entity extraction schema for historical and hagiographic texts, distinguishing persons, groups, institutions, places, objects, and divine entities.

person.description: Individual human actors mentioned in the narrative, including saints. May include attributes such as role, social background, or gender. This can also include pronouns as they refer to people

group.description: Collective human or divine actors referred to as groups (e.g., monastic community, royal court, 'the people', angels). Groups may optionally list known members. It also counts as a group if a word referring to a person or occupation is declined as plural (e.g. virignes, populi, viri, pueri). General references to a group, in vague terms do also count (e.g. 'them all', 'they', 'the inhabitors').

institution.description: Social or organizational entities such as monasteries, churches, royal palaces, or other structured communities. Treated as collective actors rather than physical locations.

place.description: Geographical or physical locations used to situate actions (e.g., cities, villages, rivers, regions, landscapes). Distinct from institutions, which represent social actors. General references to a place are also included.

object.description: Material or inanimate items relevant to the narrative or relational network (e.g., relics, books, veils, ointments). A thing that has physical existence and can be moved or used by an person, but is not alive

divine_entity.description: Unambiguously divine beings such as God, Jesus, angels, or Mary. Also alternative references to divine entities, such as 'the Lord', 'the Savior', or 'the Mother of God' are included. However, saints are not included in this category, they are included in the 'person' category.

text_title.description: Titles of texts, manuscripts, or documents mentioned in the narrative (e.g., 'The Bible', 'The Life of Saint Martin', 'The Book of Miracles').
